p.s: In the following I am going to analyze the speech by Johnson with special reward to the use of rhetorical devices and his stradegystrategy.

You can clearly see, that he uses a lot of rhetorical devices to draw a convincing picture of the dangers, to give his audience hope, to encourage them to take action and also to convince them of the COP26.
His audience are powerful people who have a big impact.
At the begginingbeginning of his speech Johnson uses aan allusion by drawing a parallel to James Bond.
Firstly he breaks the ice with a joke: who generally comes to the climax of his highly lucrative films (ll. 2-3).
After that he compares the situation of Bond with our position.
By using metaphorical langauge he describes BondsBond's situation.
He is strapped to a fictional doomsday device, so he trystries to find out which wire he needs to pull to turn it off.
Furthermore there is a digital clock ticking down until the end of a normal human life.
Johnson uses this parallel to underline our stern situation and the urgency to act.
In the following he directly adresses the audience with my fellow global leaders to involve them and make them aware that they are in the position to change something.
But afterwards he highlights that there is a big difference, because our situation is reality and the doomsday device is real (l. 7).
This comparison is great because the device can be a metaphor for climate change and global warming.
In the following Johnson points out that there were already achievements in Copenhagen and Paris, but all those promises will not work out and will be nothing but blah, blah, blah (ll. 12f).
At this point he is very pessimistic about the agreement and the aim of it.
To emotionalize he uses a personification of an anger and impatienteimpatient world (l. 13).
Only the COP26 in Glasgow would change that.
He encourages the audience that it is possible by refferingreferring to the metaphor of the doomsday device.
After that paragraph he refers to the Paris agreement which will not be enough.
We need to invest in other countries, so that they can also chagne to a green technology.
Afterwards he appeals to the audience to invest by themself and makes a clear task: working together, so everyone can decarbonize.
Furthermore we should work with multilateral development banks to create a joint progress.
At this point of his speech, Johnson compares with the UK.
Very noticeable is the inclusive language of Johnson to create a unit of people who are affected and can change something.
He is sure that collaboration and cooperation multilateralism is one key.
Later he makes clear that we have all the resources to make a change but questions the will.
Furthermore he critisizescriticizes indirectly that the average age at the meeting of leaders is over 60, while half of the population of the world watching is under 30.
There is a need for young people who are still alive and willing when the achievements hopefully are made.
In the next paragraph he looks in the future to the next generation.
Johnson thinks that there is a urgency for acting because otherwise these generations will never forgive us.
He agrees and is aware, that COP26 will not, and cannot, be the end of the story of climate change (l. 42).
Therefore we are not allowed to fail.
To spread optimism he uses an anaphora with we, because there are ideas, technology, bankers and NGOs.
In the end of the speech he finally refers again to the James Bond movie.
After joking around (l. 47) he repeats that we have no more excuses to not act.
Johnson describes the importance of this agreement with a known alliteration: make this moment when we began irrefutably to turn the tide (l. 49).
At the very end he makes clear that it will not be easy, but that it is possible as a unit.
This clearly underlines his optimism.
All in all, one can say that the politician Johnson uses a very common strategy for speeches.

He uses effective rhetorical devices metaphorical language / allusion, inclusive language, direct address, repetition, anaphora in the right places to emphasize his own opinion and follows a clear line of argument.
Because of this strategy the audience can easily follow his speech, feels involved and is convinced of his opinion.
The strong image of the destroying device and the ticking clock highlights the urgency.
Firstly he informs about the dangers, but then gives a lot of us hope to encourage to take action aftewards.
